questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of progressive difficulty swallowing solid foods and a sensation of food sticking in his throat. He also reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food, especially when lying down, but denies any weight loss, heartburn, or respiratory symptoms. Barium swallow study shows a posterior protrusion in the pharyngoesophageal region, suggesting the presence of Zenker’s diverticulum. Given the location and presentation of the patient's symptoms, which anatomical area associated with the development of Zenker's diverticulum is most relevant to this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricopharyngeus

 

Option C:

 

  • Killian's dehiscence refers to a specific area of potential weakness in the pharyngeal wall, located in the posterior aspect of the pharynx at the transition between the pharynx and esophagus.

 

 

 

  • This area is particularly relevant in the context of Zenker's diverticulum, which is a type of pharyngeal pouch that can herniate through this weak spot.
  • Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum that arises in Killian's dehiscence, an area of potential weakness between the oblique fibers of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle (thyropharyngeus) and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle.
  • This area is part of the pharyngoesophageal junction, located just above the upper esophageal sphincter. The cricopharyngeus muscle, which is part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum.
  • Increased intraluminal pressure during swallowing, due to dysfunction or incoordination of the cricopharyngeus muscle, leads to herniation of the mucosal layer through Killian's dehiscence, forming the diverticulum.
  • The nasopharynx and oropharynx are higher up in the pharyngeal anatomy and not directly involved in the formation of Zenker's diverticulum.
  • The thyropharyngeus muscle contributes to the boundary of Killian's dehiscence but is not the primary site associated with the diverticulum formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The nasopharynx is the upper part of the pharynx, lying behind the nose and above the soft palate. Killian's dehiscence is not located in the nasopharynx; it is found much lower, near the transition from the pharynx to the esophagus.

 

Option B: The oropharynx lies below the nasopharynx and extends from the soft palate to the upper edge of the epiglottis. While the oropharynx is involved in swallowing, Killian's dehiscence is not located here but rather in the lower pharyngeal region.

 

Option D: The thyropharyngeus is another part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, positioned superior to the cricopharyngeus muscle. While it contributes to the structure of the pharyngeal wall, Killian's dehiscence is specifically related to the area near the cricopharyngeus muscle rather than the thyropharyngeus muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cricopharyngeus muscle is part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle and acts as the upper esophageal sphincter.
  • Killian's dehiscence is located in the area where the muscle fibers of the cricopharyngeus part slightly, creating a potential area of weakness between the thyropharyngeus portion of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor and the cricopharyngeus muscle itself.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 224.

choices.text: Maxillary Sinus
Sphenoidal Sinus
Frontal Sinus
Ethmoidal Sinus (middle)

questions.text: A 32-year-old female had complaints of nasal stuffiness, pain over her upper jaw. On examination there was tenderness over the right and left cheek bones. The below is the CT of the patient. All the following open into the probed space except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sphenoidal sinus

 

Option B:

 

  • The probed space is the middle meatus of the nasal cavity which is situated below the middle concha.
  • It receives the opening of maxillary, frontal, anterior ethmoidal and middle ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess situated above the superior concha.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The maxillary sinus drains into the nasal cavity via the maxillary ostium, which opens into the semilunar hiatus located in the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

 

Option C. Frontal Sinus: The frontal sinus drains into the nasal cavity through the frontonasal duct, which opens into the middle meatus, typically in the region of the infundibulum.

 

Option D. Ethmoidal Sinus: The middle ethmoidal sinuses (or middle ethmoidal air cells) drain into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, specifically into the ethmoid bulla. Top of Form

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sphenoidal Sinus: The sphenoidal sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above the superior concha, not the middle meatus.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 565

questions.text: All the following nerves innervate the pointed structure except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) XII

 

Option D:

 

  • The pointed structure is soft palate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IX, X, XI nerve contributes to the pharyngeal plexus which supplies the soft palate. Vagus is motor

 

Option B. All muscles of soft palate are innervated by pharyngeal plexus except tensor veli palatini which is innervated by trunk of mandibular nerve

 

Option C. IX nerve conveys the sensations from the soft palate.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hypoglossal nerve innervates all the muscles of tongue except palatoglossus

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 131

choices.text: Posterior to Superior Turbinate
Posterior to Middle Turbinate
Posterior to Inferior Turbinate
Inferior to Superior Turbinate

questions.text: Woodruff’s Plexus is located over:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior to Inferior Turbinate

 

Option C:

 

  • Woodruff's plexus is a vascular network located on the posterior lateral wall of the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity and it is generally considered to be responsible for posterior epistaxis.
  • Sphenopalatine artery is called the artery of epistaxis

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior and middle turbinate are parts of labyrinth of ethmoid bone.

 

Option B: Anterior epistaxis results from injury to kissel bach’s plexus located over anteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option D: Inferior turbinate is the largest and is an independent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Woodruff's plexus, also known as Woodruff's area, is a venous plexus located in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, near the posterior end of the inferior nasal concha or turbinate.
  • It is situated over the posterior nasal septum and the lateral nasal wall, particularly in the region of the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • This plexus is known for being a potential source of posterior epistaxis due to its rich vascularization and location.
  • The veins of Woodruff's plexus are connected to the sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 219

questions.text: Nasal Septum is formed by ALL except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perpendicular Plate of Palatine Bone

 

Option A: The nasal septum receives minor contribution from palatine crest whereas the perpendicular plate of palatine bone contributes to lateral wall of nose.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the anterosuperior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option C: Vomer, the unpaired bone contributes to the posteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option D: Minor contribution to the septum in its posterosuperior portion comes from the sphenoidal crest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasal septum is the structure that divides the nasal cavity into two nostrils (or nasal passages). It is composed of both bone and cartilage. The nasal septum is formed by:

 

  1. Perpendicular Plate of the Ethmoid Bone: This is a thin, vertical bone that forms the superior part of the nasal septum. The ethmoid bone is one of the cranial bones and contributes significantly to the structure of the nasal cavity.

  2. Vomer Bone: The vomer is a thin, plow-shaped bone that forms the inferior and posterior parts of the nasal septum. It articulates above with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone and below with the maxillary and palatine bones.

  3. Septal Cartilage (Quadrangular Cartilage): This is a flexible cartilage that fills in the anterior part of the nasal septum. It extends from the nasal bones in the roof of the nose down to the maxillary bones in the floor.

 

Note: Do not confuse between perpendicular plate of ethmoid and palatine. The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to nasal septum whereas the perpendicular plate of palatine does not

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 20

choices.text: Superior Tonsillar Artery
Inferior Tonsillar Artery
Anterior Tonsillar Artery
Posterior Tonsillar Artery

questions.text: Principal Artery of Palatine Tonsil?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior Tonsillar Artery

 

Option B: The inferior tonsillar branch from facial artery is the principal artery to palatine tonsil.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior tonsillar is branch from descending palatine artery (maxillary artery)

 

Option C: Anterior tonsillar is branch from dorsal lingual artery (lingual artery)

 

Option D: Posterior tonsillar branches arise from facial artery ascending palatine branch and ascending pharyngeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The palatine tonsil, located in the oropharynx, receives its blood supply from several arteries, with the principal artery being the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.
     
  • This branch is often referred to as the inferior tonsillar artery, although this specific naming can vary in different texts. The importance of the tonsillar branch arises from its direct contribution to the vascular supply of the tonsil. Here's a detailed explanation:

 

  1. Facial Artery: The facial artery is a major branch of the external carotid artery. As it courses upwards along the side of the face, it gives off several branches that supply various structures, including the palatine tonsil.
     
  2. Tonsillar Branch: The tonsillar branch typically arises near the upper border of the tonsil. It enters the tonsillar fossa from below, often after giving off branches to the adjacent pharyngeal muscles and other nearby structures. Upon reaching the tonsil, the tonsillar branch penetrates the tonsillar capsule and provides the primary blood supply to the tonsil.
     
  3. Collateral Supply: Although the tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the principal artery, the tonsil also receives collateral blood supply from other arteries, including:
     
  • Ascending Palatine Artery: A branch of the facial artery that ascends on the pharyngeal wall and supplies the tonsil from its posterior aspect.
     
  • Dorsal Lingual Branches: From the lingual artery, supplying the base of the tongue and contributing to the tonsil's vascularization.
  • Ascending Pharyngeal Artery: A branch of the external carotid artery, contributing to the vascular supply of the pharynx and tonsils.
     
  • Lesser Palatine Arteries: Branches from the descending palatine artery (itself a branch of the maxillary artery), supplying the soft palate and tonsils.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 153

choices.text: Upper Deep Cervical Nodes
Lymphatic Tissue over Posterior 1/3 Tongue

questions.text: Component of Inner Waldeyer Ring are ALL Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper Deep Cervical Nodes 

 

Option A: Upper deep cervical nodes include the jugulodigastric nodes which are the principal lymph nodes of the palatine tonsil.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Tubal tonsil -part of waldeyer ring found in lateral wall of nasopharynx overlying tubal elevation.

 

Option C: Palatine tonsil part of waldeyer ring found in lateral wall of oropharynx.

 

Option D: Lymphatic tissue over posterior 1/3 tongue contribute to Lingual tonsil and part of waldeyer ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Waldeyer's ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue located in the throat and nasopharynx.
  • It forms part of the body's immune system by encircling the entrance to the pharynx and providing a defense against inhaled and ingested pathogens.
  • The Waldeyer's ring includes both outer and inner components.

 

The inner components of the Waldeyer's ring typically refer to the lymphoid tissues that are situated more deeply or posteriorly in the nasopharynx and oropharynx. These include:

 

  1. Pharyngeal Tonsil (Adenoids): Located in the roof of the nasopharynx, the pharyngeal tonsil enlarges during childhood and tends to atrophy with age. It is a significant part of the body's immune defense, especially in children.
  2. Tubal Tonsils: These are located near the openings of the Eustachian tubes in the nasopharynx. The tubal tonsils are smaller lymphoid tissues that, along with the adenoids and other components, form the ring of lymphoid tissue.
  3. Lingual Tonsil: Situated at the base of the tongue, the lingual tonsil is part of the Waldeyer's ring, contributing to the immune defense at the entrance of the oropharynx and laryngopharynx.

 

The outer components typically refer to the more anteriorly placed palatine tonsils, which are located at the sides of the throat, and sometimes the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches, which are muscular folds adjacent to the palatine tonsils.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 153

questions.text: Extrinsic Membranes of Larynx are ALL except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quadrate Membrane

 

Option A: Quadrate membrane is an intrinsic membrane, its upper margin lies in the aryepiglottic fold and lower border thickened to form vestibular membrane
 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and internal laryngeal nerve

 

 

Option C: Hyoepiglottic ligament connects lower part of anterior surface of epiglottis to hyoid bone.

 

Option D: Cricotracheal membrane extends from the lower border of anterior arch to first tracheal ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The extrinsic membranes of the larynx are connective tissue structures that connect the larynx to adjacent parts of the throat and help to support and stabilize it. There are two main extrinsic membranes of the larynx:
  1. Thyrohyoid Membrane stretches between the hyoid bone and the thyroid cartilage. It is a broad, fibroelastic sheet that connects the upper border of the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone. The thyrohyoid membrane is important for suspending the larynx from the hyoid bone and for facilitating the movement and function of the larynx during speech and swallowing. The membrane has a central and lateral part, where the lateral part is thickened to form the thyrohyoid ligament.
  2. Cricotracheal Ligament (or Membrane) connects the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, which is the base of the larynx, to the first tracheal ring, effectively joining the larynx to the trachea. It provides continuity between the larynx above and the trachea below, ensuring a stable yet flexible airway that can accommodate movements such as swallowing, neck flexion, and extension.
  • The intrinsic membranes of the larynx, often referred to as intrinsic ligaments, are a series of connective tissue structures that connect the various cartilages of the larynx to each other. Unlike the extrinsic membranes that connect the larynx to other structures in the neck, the intrinsic membranes are entirely contained within the larynx and play a crucial role in its function, including voice production and the opening and closing of the glottis. The main intrinsic membranes and ligaments include:
  1. Conus Elasticus (Cricovocal Membrane) extends from the cricoid cartilage up to the vocal ligaments. It is comprised of two parts:
      • The medial cricothyroid ligament, which is a thickened band in the midline, stretching between the cricoid and thyroid cartilages.
      • The lateral cricothyroid membranes, which extend from the cricoid cartilage to the vocal ligaments and arytenoid cartilages.
  2. Quadrangular Membranes are paired membranes that stretch between the epiglottis, the arytenoid cartilages, and the thyroid cartilage. The free lower edges of the quadrangular membranes form the vestibular ligaments (or false vocal cords), which run parallel to the true vocal cords but are located just above them.
  3. Vocal Ligaments are not membranes per se but are often included in discussions of the intrinsic structures of the larynx due to their importance in voice production. The vocal ligaments are bands of elastic tissue that stretch from the thyroid cartilage in front to the arytenoid cartilage at the back. They are covered by a layer of mucous membrane and form the core of the true vocal cords (or vocal folds).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 236

choices.text: Tonsillar Branch of Facial Artery
Ascending Palatine Artery
Descending Palatine Artery
Ascending Pharyngeal Artery

questions.text: Which of the following does not Supply Palate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tonsillar Branch of Facial Artery

 

Option A:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery primarily supplies the palatine tonsil and surrounding tissues, not the palate itself.
  • While it is in close proximity to the palate, its main function is to provide blood to the tonsillar area. Therefore, this artery does not directly supply the palate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The ascending palatine artery, a branch of the facial artery, indeed supplies the palate. It ascends between the styloglossus and stylopharyngeus muscles and contributes to the blood supply of the soft palate and tonsils.

 

Option C: Descending palatine artery, which arises from the maxillary artery, is a major supplier of blood to the hard and soft palate. It typically divides into the greater and lesser palatine arteries, which supply the hard and soft palate, respectively.

 

Option D: The ascending pharyngeal artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, primarily supplies the pharynx. While it has branches that contribute to the blood supply of the pharynx and adjacent structures, it is not a primary supplier of the palate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blood supply of the palate is derived from several branches of the maxillary artery, which is one of the two terminal branches of the external carotid artery. The main arteries supplying the palate include:

 

  1. Greater Palatine Artery is the primary artery supplying the hard palate. It descends through the greater palatine canal, emerges from the greater palatine foramen, and supplies the mucosa and glands of the hard palate, except for a small area near the alveolar margin which is supplied by the nasopalatine artery.
  2. Lesser Palatine Arteries supply the soft palate. They descend through the lesser palatine canals and emerge through the lesser palatine foramina to supply the soft palate, uvula, and tonsils.
  3. A branch of the facial artery, the ascending palatine artery, contributes to the supply of the soft palate by ascending along the pharynx.
  4. Pharyngeal Branches of the Maxillary Artery branches may also contribute to the blood supply of the soft palate.
  5. Nasopalatine Artery runs forward on the nasal septum and supplies a small part of the anterior hard palate through the incisive canal.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 131

choices.text: Greater Petrosal Nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a chronic headache localized to the forehead and behind the eyes. He also reports a decreased sense of smell and episodes of nasal congestion not relieved by over-the-counter medications. Imaging studies, including a CT scan of the sinuses, show opacification of the sphenoidal sinuses with bone remodeling. Given the location of his sinus disease, which of the following structures is most at risk of being affected by the pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vidian Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • The canal for vidian nerve/ pterygoid canal lies in the floor of the sphenoidal sinus.
  • Vidian nerve, also known as the nerve of the pterygoid canal, runs in the pterygoid canal and carries fibers from the greater petrosal nerve (parasympathetic) and the deep petrosal nerve (sympathetic).
  • It is located near the floor of the sphenoidal sinus. Pathology in the sphenoidal sinus, such as chronic inflammation, infection, or tumor, can potentially impact the Vidian nerve due to its anatomical proximity.
  • This could result in symptoms related to its autonomic functions, including altered lacrimation or salivation, though these are more subtle and less commonly reported by patients compared to the more prominent symptoms of sphenoid sinus disease like headache and nasal congestion.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mandibular nerve passes through foramen ovale in middle cranial fossa to enter infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Greater petrosal nerve arises from geniculate ganglion pierces roof of middle ear lies over the groove on it.

 

Option D: Maxillary nerve passes through foramen rotundum of middle cranial fossa to reach pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Vidian nerve, also known as the nerve of the pterygoid canal, does not lie directly over the floor of the sphenoidal sinus.
  • The structure that lies directly over the floor of the sphenoidal sinus is typically the sphenoid bone itself, which forms the roof of the nasopharynx.
  • The Vidian nerve runs in the pterygoid canal, which is situated more laterally, in the base of the skull, connecting the foramen lacerum to the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • The Vidian nerve is formed by the union of the greater petrosal nerve, carrying parasympathetic fibers, and the deep petrosal nerve, carrying sympathetic fibers.
  • This nerve travels through the pterygoid canal and ends in the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • While it is an important neural structure in the vicinity, it doesn't directly overlay the sphenoidal sinus floor but is rather related to the lateral and posterior aspects of the sphenoidal sinus within the deeper parts of the skull base.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 220

choices.text: External Laryngeal Nerve
Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve
Internal Laryngeal Nerve

questions.text: Fish Bone Area Sensory Supply:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal Laryngeal Nerve

 

Option D: Piriform fossa or the fish bone area is situated over the lateral wall of laryngopharynx and its mucosa is innervated by internal laryngeal nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: External laryngeal nerve ELN is entirely motor and supplies cricothyroid muscle which is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

Option B: Glossopharyngeal nerve carries general sensation from pharynx, tonsils, fauces and posterior 1/3 tongue.

 

Option C: Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid and is also sensory to mucosa of larynx below the level of vocal cords.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sensory supply to the piriform fossa primarily comes from the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). The internal laryngeal nerve enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the larynx above the vocal cords, including the piriform fossa.
  • The piriform fossa is a pear-shaped depression located on either side of the laryngeal inlet, between the aryepiglottic fold and the thyroid cartilage. It is an important anatomical region for swallowing, as it helps to direct food and liquids away from the airway and towards the esophagus. The sensory innervation provided by the internal laryngeal nerve is crucial for triggering the swallowing reflex and protecting the airway during ingestion.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 230

choices.text: Rima Glottis is the narrowest part of Larynx
Lateral Cricoarytenoid is the safety Muscle of Larynx
Vocal folds are pearly white in colour
Each Vocal fold contains vocal Ligament and Vocalis Muscle

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy accidentally swallowed a small magnet of his toy car. He began to suffocate and was rushed to the hospital, where an x-ray examination showed the impaction of a foreign body in the larynx. Which of the following statements is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral Cricoarytenoid is the safety muscle of Larynx

 

Option B:

 

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid which causes abduction of vocal folds is the safety muscle of larynx.
  • Rima glottidis is the narrowest anteroposterior cleft of the laryngeal cavity

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The rima glottidis, the opening between the vocal folds, is indeed the narrowest part of the larynx in children. This is particularly relevant in cases of foreign body aspiration, as objects often become lodged at this narrowest point.

 

Option C. In a healthy individual, the vocal folds are typically a pearly white color, owing to the lack of blood vessels in the vocal ligament and the overlying mucosa.

 

Option D. Each vocal fold comprises the vocal ligament and the vocalis muscle, which is part of the thyroarytenoid muscle. These structures are essential for the production of sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  The safety muscle of the larynx is the Posterior Crico-Arytenoid Muscle, not the lateral Cricoarytenoid muscle. 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg no:591

choices.text: The Earache was due to spread of the infection to inner Ear
Lymphatics from tonsil drain into Jugulo Omohyoid nodes
The Vagus Nerve has high chance of injury during Tonsillectomy
Internal Carotid artery is usually safe during Tonsillectomy

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented to ENT OPD with complaints of ear pain and throat pain for the past three days. On examination of the oral cavity showed enlargement of tonsils He had a history of similar episodes in the past which had all been treated successfully with antibiotics; however, the infections had become progressively more severe and he had missed a considerable amount of school attendance. This episode of tonsillitis also managed with antibiotics successfully, but tonsillectomy was suggested to eliminate the problem once and for all. The boy was readmitted to the hospital for surgery two weeks after his most recent infection had cleared up. Intraoperatively, suddenly there was a massive amount of bleeding. In a while the surgeon identified the bleeder and ligated it, following which the wound was closed and the patient's recovery was uneventful. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the above case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphatics from tonsil drain into Jugulo Omohyoid nodes

 

Option B:

 

  • The tonsils have a rich lymphatic supply, and lymphatic drainage from the palatine tonsils primarily goes to the jugulodigastric (jugulo-omohyoid) lymph nodes. This drainage pattern is relevant in the context of tonsillitis and can contribute to lymph node enlargement during infections.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Earache (otalgia) is a common symptom associated with tonsillitis and throat infections. However, it is usually not related to the spread of infection to the inner ear. Ear pain in tonsillitis is often referred pain, meaning that the pain in the ear is felt due to shared nerve pathways, but the infection typically does not reach the inner ear.

 

Option C. Tonsillectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of the tonsils, which are located in the throat. While the vagus nerve does pass through the neck and throat area, it is typically not at high risk of injury during routine tonsillectomy procedures. Surgeons performing tonsillectomy take care to avoid damaging important structures in the throat.

 

Option D. The palatine tonsil is supplied by five arterial branches: the ascending palatine and tonsillar branches of the facial artery, the palatine branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery, the dorsal lingual branch of the lingual artery, and the descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery. 

 

  • The primary source of hemorrhage, however, is usually the external palatine vein (Para-Tonsillar Vein). The internal carotid artery is usually safe during the procedure. 
  • (If compare ICA Vs ECA) - The Internal Carotid Artery lies 2.5cm behind and lateral to tonsillar Sinus (External carotid artery is not affected because it divides into its terminal branches opposite the neck of Mandible into the Superficial Temporal Artery & Maxillary artery.

 

Educational Objective:

  • The palatine tonsils drain into the jugulodigastric lymph nodes, important for understanding the spread of infection and lymph node involvement in tonsillitis.
  • Recurrent tonsillitis that affects daily activities such as school attendance might be managed surgically through tonsillectomy, which while generally safe, carries risks such as significant bleeding typically from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery, not the internal carotid artery

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 129

choices.text: Contains taste buds
Contains mucus secreting gland
Lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium

questions.text: False about the pointed structure:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perichondrium absent 

 

Option C:

 

The pointed structure is Epiglottis. It is made up of elastic cartilage. Perichondrium is present in elastic cartilage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The epiglottis does contain taste buds on its laryngeal surface. These taste buds are involved in the sensory aspects of swallowing and help trigger the swallowing reflex.

 

Option B. The epiglottis contains mucus-secreting glands. These glands play a role in lubricating the larynx and the vocal cords, aiding in the protection of these structures and in the swallowing process.

 

Option D. The laryngeal surface of the epiglottis is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium is typical in the upper respiratory tract, where it helps in the movement of mucus and trapped particles. 

Note - Whole of Larynx is lined by Ciliated Columnar Epithelium except Vocal Cords & Upper Surface of Epiglottis is lined by Stratified Squamous Epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiglottis, like other cartilaginous structures in the body, is covered by perichondrium, a dense layer of connective tissue that provides nutrients to the cartilage. The presence of perichondrium is a normal feature of cartilaginous structures, including the epiglottis

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 238

questions.text: Abduction of vocal cord is done by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Option D:

 

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid causes abduction of vocal cord.
  • The Posterior Cricoarytenoid muscle is the only muscle in the larynx that abducts the vocal cords, meaning it pulls them apart. This action is essential for breathing, as it opens the glottis to allow air to flow into the lungs. It is the primary muscle responsible for keeping the airway open during respiration

 

The marked structure in the given image:

 

  1. Cricothyroid
  2. Thyroarytenoid
  3. Lateral Cricoarytenoid
  4. Posterior Cricoarytenoid

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Cricothyroid muscle lengthens and tenses the vocal cords by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward relative to the cricoid cartilage. This action increases the pitch of the voice by making the vocal cords longer and tighter, which is essential for producing higher-frequency sounds.

 

Option B. The Thyroarytenoid muscle, including its internal part known as the vocalis muscle, shortens and relaxes the vocal cords. This action decreases the tension on the vocal cords, lowering the pitch of the voice. The Thyroarytenoid muscle is the main muscle within the body of the vocal cords and contributes to their mass and tension, affecting vocal quality.

 

Option C. The Lateral Cricoarytenoid muscle adducts the vocal cords, meaning it brings them together. This action is crucial for phonation (producing sound) as it closes the glottis (the space between the vocal cords). The muscle plays a key role in voice modulation and is active when speaking or singing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid causes abduction of vocal cord.
  •  The Posterior Cricoarytenoid muscle is the only muscle in the larynx that abducts the vocal cords, meaning it pulls them apart. This action is essential for breathing, as it opens the glottis to allow air to flow into the lungs. It is the primary muscle responsible for keeping the airway open during respiration.

           

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 244

choices.text: Closure of Laryngeal inlet
Opening of Laryngeal inlet

questions.text: Action of the pointed structure on vocal cord:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Opening of Laryngeal inlet

 

Option C:

 

The marked muscle in the given image is Thyroepiglottic muscle.

 

Thyroepiglottic causes opening of laryngeal inlet.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Closure of laryngeal inlet is caused by aryepiglotticus muscle

 

Option B. Adduction of rima glottis is caused by transverse arytenoid, oblique arytenoid and lateral cricoarytenoid

 

Option D. Relaxation of vocal cord is caused by vocalis, thyroarytenoid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thyroepiglottic causes opening of laryngeal inlet.
  • The thyroepiglottic muscle plays a role in the opening of the laryngeal inlet, which is the entrance to the larynx (voice box) from the pharynx (throat). This muscle is part of the internal laryngeal muscles and is involved in the regulation of the laryngeal opening.
  • When the thyroepiglottic muscle contracts, it pulls the epiglottis away from the laryngeal inlet, thereby widening the opening. This action is important for allowing air to pass freely into the larynx during breathing and helps in preventing aspiration of food and liquids into the airway during swallowing. The thyroepiglottic muscle, along with other muscles and structures of the larynx, works in a coordinated manner to protect the airway and to control the passage of air and food appropriately.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 244

choices.text: Middle Ethmoidal Sinus
Posterior Ethmoidal Sinus

questions.text: The probed space receives the opening of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasolacrimal Duct

 

Option A:

 

  • The probed space is inferior meatus which receives the opening of nasolacrimal duct.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Maxillary sinus opens into middle meatus into the floor of hiatus semilunaris.

 

Option C. Middle ethmoidal sinus opens into middle meatus on surface of bulla ethmoidalis.

 

Option D. Posterior ethmoidal cells opens into superior meatus

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inferior meatus receives the opening of nasolacrimal duct.
  • The inferior meatus is indeed the location within the nasal cavity where the nasolacrimal duct opens. The nasolacrimal duct is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac, which collects tears from the eyes, into the nasal cavity. This duct allows for the tears, along with any debris or foreign particles collected from the eye surface, to be flushed into the nasal cavity and then swallowed or expelled.
  • The opening of the nasolacrimal duct into the inferior meatus is a key component of the lacrimal apparatus, which is involved in tear production and drainage. This anatomical arrangement explains why your nose may run when you cry, as tears from the eyes overflow into the nasal cavity. Issues with the nasolacrimal duct, such as blockages, can lead to tear drainage problems, resulting in watery eyes or infections.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 217

questions.text: Which of the following two marked structures share the same nerve supply:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B & D

 

Option B:

 

B-Palatine tonsil and D-Circumvallate papillae: These structures share a significant part of their nerve supply through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which provides sensory innervation to the palatine tonsils and taste sensation to the circumvallate papillae.

 

The structure marked in the above image are:

 

  1. Vallecula
  2. Palatine tonsil
  3. Palatoglossus muscle
  4. Circumvallate papillae.

 

A. The valleculae are depressions located at the base of the tongue, just in front of the epiglottis. Their sensory innervation primarily comes from the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

B. The palatine tonsils are located on the sides of the oropharynx. Their sensory innervation is provided by several nerves, including branches from the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and lesser contributions from the pharyngeal plexus.

 

C. Palatoglossus muscle is one of the muscles of the soft palate and also contributes to the formation of the anterior tonsillar pillar. It is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with motor innervation primarily coming from the vagus nerve (CN X), via its pharyngeal branches.

 

D. Circumvallate Papillae is located at the back of the tongue, these papillae contain taste buds and are innervated for taste by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for their posterior one-third of the tongue location.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A&B (Vallecula & Palatine Tonsil): These structures do not share the same primary nerve supply. The vallecula is mainly innervated by the vagus nerve (via the superior laryngeal nerve), while the palatine tonsil is primarily innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

 

Option C. C&D (Palatoglossus Muscle & Circumvallate Papillae): The palatoglossus muscle and the circumvallate papillae do not share the same nerve supply. The palatoglossus muscle is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus (mainly the vagus nerve, CN X), while the circumvallate papillae are innervated for taste by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

 

Option D. A&C (Vallecula & Palatoglossus Muscle): These structures do not share the same primary nerve supply. The vallecula is mainly innervated by the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve, CN X), and the palatoglossus muscle is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus (also predominantly by the vagus nerve, CN X), but their specific functions and innervation patterns do not overlap significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

B & D: Glossopharyngeal nerve carries general sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue, taste sensation from circumvallate papillae and also conveys general sensation from palatine tonsil.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 147

choices.text: Superficial Cervical Nodes

questions.text: Where does the pointed structure drain into?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submandibular Nodes

 

Option D: The pointed structure is the frontal sinus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Retro auricular nodes/Mastoid nodes drain part of auricle, scalp and posterior wall of External Acoustic Meatus.

 

Option B: Preauricular lymph nodes belong to superficial group of parotid nodes and lie in front of tragus.

 

Option C: Superficial cervical nodes receive lymph from the floor of external acoustic meatus, lobule of ear, angle of mandible and lower part of parotid region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frontal sinus, most of the ethmoidal sinus and maxillary sinus drain into submandibular lymph nodes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 221

questions.text: Where does the pointed structure open into?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal Recess

 

Option D:

 

  • The pointed structure is indicating the location of sphenoid sinus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior meatus receives the posterior ethmoidal sinus.

 

 

Option B: Middle meatus receives maxillary sinus, frontal sinus, anterior ethmoidal and middle ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option C: Inferior meatus receives the nasolacrimal duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: It opens into sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 217

choices.text: Hoarseness of Voice, Aspiration

questions.text: Paralysis of the pointed structure will result in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weak Voice

 

Option B:

 

  • Pointed structure is cricothyroid muscle whose injury will result into weak voice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid and is sensory to the mucosa of the larynx below the level of vocal cords. Its injury will result in hoarseness and aspiration.

 

Option C: Injury to internal laryngeal nerve also will result in aspiration, it is sensory to mucosa of larynx above the level of vocal cords.

 

Option D: Recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates posterior cricoarytenoid muscle which is an abductor of vocal cord. Its paralysis vocal cord will lie in cadaveric position and cause dyspnoea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cricothyroid muscle, innervated by external laryngeal nerves and is a tensor of the vocal cord. Its paralysis will result in weak voice.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 244

choices.text: Internal Laryngeal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following Structure does not pass through the Gap between Superior and Middle Constrictor of Pharynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal Laryngeal Nerve

 

Option A: Internal laryngeal nerve branch of superior laryngeal nerve from vagus pierces thyrohyoid membrane and supplies mucosa of larynx above vocal cords. It does not pass through the gap between superior and middle constrictor of pharynx.

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing through them

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glossopharyngeal nerve is the nerve of the third pharyngeal arch that innervates stylopharyngeus muscle and passes between the superior and middle constrictor of pharynx.

 

Option B: Stylopharyngeus, Salpingopharyngeus and Palatopharyngeus are the longitudinal muscles of pharynx. All muscles of pharynx are innervated by pharyngeal plexus contributed by IX, X and XI cranial nerve. Stylopharygeus muscle is present between the superior and middle constrictor pharynx.

 

Option D: Stylohyoid ligament is derived from reichert's cartilage of 2nd pharyngeal arch. It is also present between the superior and middle constrictor of pharynx muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gap between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx, also known as the Sinus of Morgagni, allows passage for several structures, including:
    1. The stylopharyngeus muscle, which is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
    2. The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) itself.
    3. The pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) along with some pharyngeal vessels.
  • A structure that does not pass through this gap is the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • The internal laryngeal nerve, along with the superior laryngeal artery (a branch of the superior thyroid artery), actually passes through the thyrohyoid membrane, which is located more inferiorly, between the hyoid bone and the thyroid cartilage, and not through the gap between the superior and middle constrictor muscles.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 231

choices.text: Anterior Ethmoidal Sinus
Posterior Ethmoidal Sinus
Middle Ethmoidal Sinus

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ENT clinic with a chronic stuffy nose, facial pain, and a reduced sense of smell. She reports that these symptoms have persisted for several months and are not relieved by over-the-counter allergy medications. A CT scan of the sinuses reveals opacification of the ethmoid air cells, suggestive of chronic ethmoid sinusitis. The ENT specialist explains that understanding the anatomy of the ethmoid sinuses and their drainage pathways is crucial for planning her treatment, which may include endoscopic sinus surgery. Given the focus on the ethmoid sinuses, which of the following ethmoidal sinuses is correctly matched with its drainage site into the bulla ethmoidalis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle Ethmoidal Sinus

 

Option C:

 

  • The middle meatus presents the bulla ethmoidalis, a bony bulge which contains the middle ethmoidal sinuses that open onto the surface of the bulla.

 

 

  • The ethmoid sinus is divided into anterior, middle, and posterior air cells based on their drainage pathways.
  • The middle ethmoidal sinuses typically drain into the ethmoid bulla, which is a bony prominence located within the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.
  • The anterior ethmoidal sinuses usually drain into the semilunar hiatus, which is also in the middle meatus but anterior to the ethmoid bulla.
  • The posterior ethmoidal sinuses drain into the superior meatus, which is above the middle meatus.
  • The maxillary sinus, on the other hand, drains into the middle meatus but does so under the middle nasal concha, into an area called the semilunar hiatus, and not directly into the bulla ethmoidalis.
  • Understanding these drainage patterns is essential in diagnosing and treating sinusitis, as obstruction of these drainage pathways can lead to sinus infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anterior ethmoidal sinus opens into the wall of the ethmoidal infundibulum in middle meatus.

 

Option B: Posterior ethmoidal sinus opens into superior meatus.

 

Option D: Maxillary sinus, largest of the paranasal sinus opens into the floor of hiatus semilunaris in middle meatus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The middle ethmoidal air cells open into the bulla ethmoidalis.
  • The bulla ethmoidalis is a bony prominence located within the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, and it is part of the ethmoid bone.
  • The ethmoid sinus is divided into anterior, middle, and posterior air cells, and the middle ethmoidal air cells specifically drain into the semilunar hiatus, which lies adjacent to the bulla ethmoidalis.
  • This drainage pattern is an important aspect of the anatomy and physiology of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, particularly in relation to sinus ventilation and drainage.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 215

choices.text: Levator Veli Palatini

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to recurrent middle ear infections and noticeable nasal regurgitation while drinking fluids. His speech development is slightly delayed, and his parents report that his voice has a nasal quality. Examination reveals a high-arched palate and bifid uvula. Which of the following structures, potentially affected by the underlying anatomical anomaly, is most likely contributing to this child's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levator Veli Palatini

 

Option D:

 

  • The levator veli palatini muscle is crucial for elevating the soft palate during swallowing and speech, helping to separate the nasopharynx from the oropharynx.
  • This action prevents food and fluids from entering the nasal cavity during swallowing and contributes to the proper resonance of speech sounds.
  • The sinus of Morgagni is an anatomical space through which the levator veli palatini muscle passes.
  • In the context of a high-arched palate and bifid uvula, there may be an underlying submucous cleft palate or a related congenital anomaly affecting the function of the levator veli palatini muscle.
  • This dysfunction can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency, where there is inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter during swallowing and speech, resulting in symptoms such as nasal regurgitation of fluids and a nasal quality to the voice.
  • Recurrent middle ear infections can also be related to dysfunction of the muscles that open the Eustachian tube, such as the tensor veli palatini (not listed), leading to poor aeration of the middle ear and accumulation of fluids.
  • This scenario suggests the involvement of the levator veli palatini muscle in the child's clinical picture, consistent with the described symptoms.
  • Levatorveli palatini, auditory tube, ascending palatine artery and palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery pass through sinus of Morgagni.

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing through them

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Palatoglossus is innervated by pharyngeal plexus forms anterior pillar for tonsillar fossa.

 

Option B: Palatopharyngeus forms posterior pillar for tonsillar fossa and forms passavant's ridge.

 

Option C: Tensor tympani, muscle of middle ear, its contractions dampen sound vibrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sinus of Morgagni, also known as the gap or space between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles, allows for the passage of several important structures into the pharynx. These include:

 

  1. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) passes through this gap to provide sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue, the oropharynx, and the tonsils. It also carries taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue.
  2. Stylopharyngeus muscle, which is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve, passes through the sinus of Morgagni. It elevates the pharynx during swallowing and speech.
  3. While the lingual artery primarily supplies the tongue, some of its branches or the artery itself may pass near or through this region as it ascends to the tongue.
  4. Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve (CN X) may also pass through or in close proximity to this gap, contributing to the innervation of the pharynx.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 233

choices.text: Crypta Magna is situated close to the lower pole of Tonsil
Middle Constrictor Muscle forms lateral relation for Tonsil
Paratonsillar Vein is located in the Peritonsillar space
The Hypoglossal Nerve is in danger of injury during Tonsillectomy

questions.text: A mother brought her 6-year-old son to the hospital with complaints of frequent episodes sore throat in the past one month. On examination of the oral cavity the palatine tonsils almost touched each other in the midline. Which of the following statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paratonsillar Vein is located in the Peritonsillar space

 

Option C:

 

  • Peritonsillar space separates the tonsillar hemi capsule from the tonsillar bed. It consists of loose areolar tissue and paratonsillar vein. During tonsilectomy injury to this vein can cause bleeding.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crypta Magna is situated close to the lower pole of tonsil: Crypta Magna refers to a large tonsillar crypt, but it is not typically characterized as being specifically close to the lower pole of the tonsil. The tonsillar crypts are spread throughout the tonsils.

 

 

Option B. The tonsil is actually situated in the tonsillar bed, which is bordered laterally by the superior constrictor muscle of the pharynx, not the middle constrictor muscle. The middle constrictor muscle is located inferiorly to the tonsil.

 

Option D. The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII), which innervates the tongue muscles, is not typically at risk during a tonsillectomy. The nerve that is more at risk is the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which provides sensory innervation to the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paratonsillar vein is an important anatomical structure in the peritonsillar space and is of clinical significance, especially in conditions like peritonsillar abscess and during tonsillectomy, as it can be a source of bleeding.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 576

choices.text: Accumulation of pus in the maxillary sinus is drained through the middle meatus of nasal cavity
The infraorbital nerve travels in the roof of maxillary sinus
Growth in the maxillary sinus spreads anteriorly, medially, posteriorly and upwards
Maxillary sinus is described as reservoir of frontal sinus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male visited ENT OPD with complaints of recurrent sinusitis, weight loss and severe pain in upper teeth and left cheek. On examination it was noted that his left cheek was swollen and there was proptosis of left eye. CT scan confirmed presence of growth inside the left maxillary sinus. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of pus in the maxillary sinus is drained through the middle meatus of nasal cavity

 

Option A:

 

  • Accumulation of pus in the maxillary sinus is drained by a method called antral puncture through the middle meatus of nasal cavity.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2), travels in the floor of the orbit, not in the roof of the maxillary sinus. It runs in the infraorbital groove, canal, and eventually exits via the infraorbital foramen.

 

Option C. A tumor or growth in the maxillary sinus can potentially spread in various directions, including anteriorly towards the face, medially towards the nasal cavity, posteriorly towards the pterygopalatine fossa, and upwards into the orbit, as evidenced by the patient's proptosis.

 

Option D. The maxillary sinus is not typically described as a "reservoir" of the frontal sinus. Each paranasal sinus, including the maxillary and frontal sinuses, has its own distinct drainage pathway and function. The frontal sinus drains independently into the nasal cavity via the frontonasal duct, which opens into the middle meatus but is not directly connected to the maxillary sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  The maxillary sinus drains into the nasal cavity via the maxillary ostium, which opens into the semilunar hiatus located in the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 568

questions.text: Identify the tongue muscle that does not develop from somites:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Option C. 

  • The palatoglossus muscle is unique among the tongue muscles. It is part of both the tongue and the soft palate, functioning to elevate the back of the tongue and lower the soft palate.
  • Importantly, it is innervated by the vagus nerve, unlike the other tongue muscles which are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve. 
  • The palatoglossus muscle develops from the fourth pharyngeal arch, not from somites, making it distinct from the other tongue muscles in its embryological origin.

 

In the given image, structures are:

A-Hyoglossus

B-Genioglossus

C-Palatoglossus

D-Styloglossus

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The hyoglossus muscle is one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It originates from the hyoid bone and is involved in depressing and retracting the tongue. Like most of the extrinsic tongue muscles, it develops from the first pharyngeal arch, not from somites.

 

Option B: The genioglossus muscle is also an extrinsic muscle of the tongue, originating from the mandible. It is responsible for protruding the tongue. This muscle, too, develops from the first pharyngeal arch and not from somites. Genioglossus also develops from the occipital somites.

 

Option D. The styloglossus muscle, another extrinsic muscle of the tongue, originates from the styloid process of the temporal bone. It is involved in retracting and elevating the tongue. Like the hyoglossus and genioglossus, the styloglossus develops from the first pharyngeal arch and not from somites.

 

Educational Objective:

  • All muscles of the tongue are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve except the palatoglossus which is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus. 
  • All muscles of tongue develop from pre-occipital myotomes of paraxial mesoderm, except palatoglossus which is a derivative of the mesoderm of pharyngeal arc.

 

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 142

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerve will lead to the hoarseness of voice and stridor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Option D:

 

  • Right recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid and is also sensory to the mucosa of larynx below the level of vocal cords.
  • Injury to this will result in hoarseness of voice, difficulty in breathing and aspiration.

 

The marked structure in the given diagram are:

 

  1. Phrenic Nerve
  2. Vagus Nerve
  3. Cervical part of Sympathetic trunk
  4. Right recurrent Laryngeal Nerve

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phrenic nerve, from ventral rami of cervical plexus C3, C4, C5 is motor to the diaphragm and sensory to central part of diaphragmatic pleura, mediastinal pleura and pericardium.

 

Option B. Vagus nerve in neck provides superior laryngeal branch, cardiac branches, pharyngeal branch, right recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. Cervical part of sympathetic trunk, superior cervical ganglia lies opposite to C6 vertebra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Right recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid and is also sensory to the mucosa of larynx below the level of vocal cords.
  • Injury to this will result in stridor.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 244

choices.text: Arytenoid Lower Part

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive hoarseness and difficulty swallowing over the past few months. He has a history of smoking and occasional alcohol use. During the Laryngoscopic Examination, the otolaryngologist observes some changes in the structure and mobility of the laryngeal cartilages, which are considered in the differential diagnosis, including possible laryngeal osteoarthritis or ossification-related stiffness, given the patient's age and smoking history. Considering the potential for ossification of laryngeal cartilages with advancing age and its implications for laryngeal function, which of the following laryngeal cartilages does not undergo ossification, and thus, would be less likely to contribute directly to the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cuneiform

 

Option C:

 

  • The cartilages of larynx that does not undergo ossification includes - Epiglottis, Corniculate, Cuneiform, Apex and Vocal process of arytenoid which are all made of elastic cartilage.

 

 

  • The cuneiform cartilages are two small, elongated pieces of elastic cartilage located within the aryepiglottic folds of the larynx.
  • Unlike the thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid cartilages, which are hyaline cartilages and may undergo ossification as part of the aging process, the cuneiform cartilages typically do not ossify.
  • Ossification of the hyaline cartilages of the larynx can lead to changes in voice and swallowing function due to reduced mobility and flexibility of the laryngeal framework.
  • However, since the cuneiform cartilages remain elastic and do not ossify, they would be less likely to contribute to the stiffness and functional impairment that might be observed in conditions affecting the ossified laryngeal cartilages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Thyroid is unpaired laryngeal cartilage made of hyaline cartilage; hence it undergoes ossification.

 

Option B: Cricoid cartilage is unpaired laryngeal cartilage and also made of hyaline and is positioned at C6 vertebral level.

 

Option D: Arytenoid are paired cartilages of larynx and made of hyaline cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The epiglottis and cuneiform are the cartilage of the larynx that typically does not undergo ossification.
  • The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped piece of elastic cartilage that sits above the glottis and is attached to the thyroid cartilage. Its primary function is to seal off the windpipe during eating, so that food is not accidentally inhaled.
  • While most other cartilaginous structures in the larynx, such as the thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid cartilages, tend to ossify to varying degrees with age, the epiglottis and cuneiform largely retains its cartilaginous structure throughout life.
  • This is due to its composition of elastic cartilage, which is more flexible and less prone to calcification compared to the hyaline cartilage that makes up other laryngeal cartilages.


Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 236

choices.text: It winds around the second part of Subclavian Artery
It winds around arch of Aorta
It winds around third part of Subclavian Artery
It winds around first part of Subclavian Artery

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It winds around first part of Subclavian Artery

 

Option D:

 

  • The pointed structure is Right recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from right vagus in neck and ascends in trachea esophageal groove.

 

Option B. Left recurrent laryngeal nerve is given off from left vagus in thorax and it winds around arch of aorta.

 

Option C. The third part of subclavian artery is seen in posterior triangle of neck and continues as axillary artery into upper limb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Right recurrent laryngeal nerve winds around the first part of subclavian artery in scaleno vertebral triangle.
  • Right recurrent laryngeal nerve branches off the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) and winds around the right subclavian artery before ascending in the neck to reach the larynx. This anatomical route is specific to the right side of the body.
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a different pathway. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve branches off the vagus nerve and winds around the aortic arch, specifically around the ligamentum arteriosum, before ascending towards the larynx.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 410

choices.text: It is bounded laterally by Lamina of Thyroid cartilage
It lies Lateral to the Aryepiglottic fold
It lies in the Lateral wall of Larynx
It is traversed by internal Laryngeal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It lies in the lateral wall of Larynx

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is the pyriform fossa/smugglers pouch.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is true. The pyriform fossa is indeed bounded laterally by the lamina of the thyroid cartilage. The thyroid cartilage provides structural support to the larynx and part of its lamina forms the lateral boundary of the pyriform fossa.

 

Option B. This statement is also true. The aryepiglottic fold is a ridge of mucous membrane that extends from the side of the epiglottis to the arytenoid cartilage, and the pyriform fossa is situated lateral to this fold. The aryepiglottic folds play a role in the closure of the laryngeal inlet during swallowing.

 

Option D. This statement is true. The internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve itself a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), does traverse the area near the pyriform fossa. It provides sensory innervation to the mucosa above the vocal cords, including the area of the pyriform fossa. The nerve's proximity to the pyriform fossa is clinically significant, particularly during procedures like endotracheal intubation or when assessing for nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  The pyriform fossa is located in the lateral wall of the laryngopharynx, not the larynx. The laryngopharynx is the part of the pharynx that lies behind the larynx and extends from the upper border of the epiglottis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, where it becomes continuous with the esophagus.
  • The pyriform fossa is indeed an anatomical structure located in the lateral wall of the laryngopharynx, also known as the hypopharynx. There are two pyriform fossae, one on each side of the laryngeal opening. Each pyriform fossa is a pear-shaped recess that plays a significant role in the swallowing mechanism. Here are some key points about the pyriform fossa:

 

1. Location: The pyriform fossae are situated on either side of the laryngeal inlet, forming part of the lateral walls of the laryngopharynx. They extend from the level of the hyoid bone to the esophageal inlet.

 

2. Function: The pyriform fossae are involved in the swallowing process. They act as channels that help direct food and liquid laterally around the laryngeal inlet and into the esophagus, thus protecting the airway during swallowing.

 

3. Clinical Relevance: The pyriform fossa is an important landmark in the field of otolaryngology and head and neck surgery. It is a common site for hypopharyngeal cancers, and its anatomy is crucial for procedures involving the upper airway and esophagus. Foreign bodies can also become lodged in the pyriform fossa, leading to dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) or even aspiration.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 230

choices.text: Middle Nasal Concha

questions.text: The size of opening of the pointed paranasal sinus is reduced by all the following bones except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle Nasal Concha

 

Option B:

 

The pointed structure is maxillary sinus.

 

In disarticulated skull the base of the sinus presents the maxillary hiatus as a large opening which is reduced in size by the following bones:

 

  • Uncinate process of ethmoid bones from above
  • Ethmoid process of inferior nasal concha from below
  • Descending process of lacrimal bones from front
  • Perpendicular plate of palatine bone from behind.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lacrimal bone does not significantly contribute to the size of the opening of the maxillary sinus. It is a small, thin bone that forms part of the medial wall of the orbit. The maxillary sinus opens into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, and the lacrimal bone is not directly involved in this area.

 

Option C. The palatine bone contributes to the formation of the walls of the nasal cavity and is involved in the structure surrounding the maxillary sinus. However, it does not significantly impact the size of the opening of the maxillary sinus. It forms part of the floor and lateral wall of the nasal cavity but not the area where the sinus drains.

 

Option D. The ethmoid bone is indeed involved in the structure around the maxillary sinus, particularly in forming the medial wall of the sinus. It can affect the size of the maxillary sinus opening as it contains the ethmoidal air cells and forms part of the lateral nasal wall adjacent to the sinus opening.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The middle nasal concha is not a bone that reduces the size of the opening of the maxillary sinus. In fact, the maxillary sinus opens under the middle nasal concha, specifically into the semilunar hiatus located in the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. The middle nasal concha is part of the ethmoid bone and plays a role in dividing the nasal cavity but does not contribute to the size of the maxillary sinus opening.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 221

choices.text: Anterior wall presents frontonasal duct
Lymphatics drain into submandibular lymph nodes
It is present in rudimentary form at birth

questions.text: Identify the correct statement pertaining to the pointed structure in the above image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphatics drain into submandibular lymph nodes

 

Option C:

 

  • Pointed structure is frontal sinus. Blood supply is from supraorbital vessels.
  • The frontal sinus is one of the four sets of paranasal sinuses and is located in the frontal bone, just above the eyes.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. The frontal sinuses are typically paired, with one sinus located on each side of the midline within the frontal bone. However, there can be variations in size and shape, and in some cases, one sinus may be absent. It consists of two halves, within the two tables of squamous part of frontal bone.

 

Option B. The frontal sinuses drain into the nasal cavity, the drainage pathway for the frontal sinus is through the frontal recess, which leads into the ethmoidal infundibulum, and then into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.  The frontonasal duct is present on its floor.

 

Option D. The frontal sinuses are not fully developed at birth. They begin to develop as outpouchings of the ethmoid sinuses and are usually rudimentary during infancy. The frontal sinuses start to pneumatize (expand and fill with air) and become more distinct during childhood, continuing to grow and develop into adolescence and early adulthood. All sinuses are present in rudimentary form at birth except frontal sinus which start development two or three years after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frontal sinus - arterial supply is from supraorbital artery and venous drainage into the supraorbital and superior ophthalmic vessels.
  • Lymphatics drains into submandibular lymph nodes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 221

choices.text: Anteriorly - Frontal Sinus
Superiorly - Optic Nerve
Laterally - Cavernous Sinus

questions.text: Which of the following relations mentioned about the pointed structure is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laterally: Cavernous Sinus

 

Option D:

 

The pointed structure is Sphenoid sinus.

 

The Sphenoid sinus is one of the paranasal sinuses located within the sphenoid bone, deep in the skull, behind the nasal cavity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anteriorly – Frontal Sinus

 

  • The frontal sinuses are located above the eyes, in the frontal bone, which forms the forehead. The sphenoid sinuses are not directly in front of the frontal sinuses; instead, they are situated more posteriorly, deeper within the skull. The ethmoid sinuses would be found between the frontal and sphenoid sinuses.

 

Option B. Inferiorly - Oropharynx

 

  • The oropharynx is part of the throat located behind the oral cavity. While the sphenoid sinus is superior to the oropharynx, it is not directly above it in a way that would suggest a direct relationship. The sphenoid sinus is located more superiorly and anteriorly relative to the oropharynx.

 

Option C. Superiorly - Optic Nerve

 

  • The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) runs posteriorly from the eyes to the brain. The sphenoid sinus is located inferiorly to the optic nerve as it passes through the optic canal, which is superior to the sphenoid sinus. This relationship is particularly important because inflammation or expansion of the sphenoid sinus can affect the optic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On each side it is related to cavernous sinus and internal carotid artery.
  • The cavernous sinuses are large venous channels located on either side of the sella turcica, a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone that houses the pituitary gland. The lateral walls of the sphenoid sinus are indeed adjacent to the cavernous sinuses. This proximity is clinically significant because infections or other pathologies in the sphenoid sinus can potentially spread to the cavernous sinus, leading to serious complications.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 221

questions.text: Internal laryngeal nerve passes between:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B & C

 

Option B:

 

  • Internal laryngeal nerve passes between B (Middle constrictor) and C (thyropharyngeus part of Inferior constrictor).

 

The marked structure in the given image are:

 

  1. Superior constrictor.
  2. Middle constrictor.
  3. Thyropharyngeus part of Inferior constrictor.
  4. Cricopharyngeus part of inferior constrictor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IX nerve and stylopharyngeus muscle will pass in the interval between superior constrictor and middle.

 

Option C. The pharyngeal wall is weak between C and D and produces pulsion diverticulum due to neuromuscular incoordination.

 

Option D. The recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels pass below cricopharyngeus part of inferior constrictor.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Internal laryngeal nerve passes between B (Middle constrictor) and C (thyropharyngeus part of Inferior constrictor).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 233

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures forms the Superior Boundary for Piriform Fossa?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Option A: The lateral glossoepiglottic fold/pharyngoepiglottic fold forms the upper boundary for the piriform fossa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Palatoglossal arch has the palatoglossus muscle covered by the mucosa and forms the anterior boundary for tonsillar fossa.

 

Option C: Vallecula the depression between medial and lateral glossoepiglottic folds.

 

Option D: Palatopharyngeal arch containing the palatopharyngeus muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The piriform fossa, an important anatomical structure in the throat, is part of the hypopharynx. It is located on either side of the laryngeal opening. The boundaries of the piriform fossa are as follows:
    1. Medial Boundary: The medial boundary of the piriform fossa is the aryepiglottic fold. This fold is a mucosal structure that extends from the side of the epiglottis to the arytenoid cartilage of the larynx.
    2. Lateral Boundary: The lateral boundary is formed by the thyroid cartilage and the thyrohyoid membrane. This area is significant as it provides a surface against which food is directed during swallowing.
    3. Anterior Boundary: Anteriorly, the boundary is the posterior surface of the thyroid cartilage and the cricothyroid joint. This area is directly adjacent to the laryngeal inlet.
    4. Posterior Boundary: Posteriorly, the piriform fossa is bounded by the mucosa covering the cervical vertebrae. This area forms the posterior wall of the hypopharynx.
    5. Inferior Boundary: Inferiorly, the piriform fossa extends to the level where the hypopharynx joins the esophagus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 230

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not provide blood supply to the structure indicated by the pointed arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lingual Artery

 

Option B:

 

  • The pointed area is the anteroinferior portion of nasal septum.
  • The Little’s area has the kiesselbach's plexus

 

Explanation

 

Option A: Anterior ethmoidal branch - Ophthalmic artery - Internal carotid artery.

 

Option C: Septal branch of Facial artery: External carotid artery.

 

Option D: Greater palatine artery, Sphenopalatine artery - maxillary artery - External carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Little's area, also known as Kiesselbach's plexus, is a region in the anterior part of the nasal septum that is prone to epistaxis. The blood supply to Little's area is quite rich and comes from several arteries, which form an anastomosis in this region. These arteries include:

  1. Anterior Ethmoidal Artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, which itself is a branch of the internal carotid artery. It supplies the anterior and superior parts of the nasal septum.
  2. Posterior Ethmoidal Artery: Although its contribution is less significant than the anterior ethmoidal artery, the posterior ethmoidal artery also supplies blood to this region. It's another branch of the ophthalmic artery.
  3. Sphenopalatine Artery is the terminal branch of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery. It enters the nasal cavity through the sphenopalatine foramen and supplies the posterior and superior parts of the nasal septum.
  4. Greater Palatine Artery, another branch of the maxillary artery, ascends to the nasal cavity through the incisive canal and contributes to the blood supply of the anterior part of the nasal septum.
  5. Superior Labial Artery: A branch of the facial artery (from the external carotid artery), the superior labial artery supplies the anterior part of the nasal septum near the nostrils.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 218

questions.text: Into which lymph nodes does the lymphatic drainage primarily occur for the structure indicated by the pointed arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jugulodigastric Node

 

Option D: The pointed structure is Palatine tonsil.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Submandibular nodes are located in a digastric triangle beneath deep cervical fascia. It is crossed superficially by marginal mandibular nerve.

 

Option B: Submental nodes receive from tip of tongue, central part of lower lip, floor of mouth, lingual and labial gums opposite lower incisor teeth.

 

Option C: Jugulo-Omoyoid nodes lie on IJV above the intermediate tendon of omohyoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphatics from palatine tonsil mainly drain into jugulodigastric nodes.
  • Jugulodigastric nodes receive lymph also from posterior 1/3 tongue

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 153

choices.text: External Carotid Artery
Internal Carotid Artery

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not affected during tonsillectomy procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External Carotid Artery

 

Option B:

 

  • The common carotid artery divides at the upper border of the lamina of thyroid cartilage into internal and external carotid arteries.
  • The external carotid artery divides into its terminal branches opposite the neck of mandible into superficial temporal and maxillary artery.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glossopharyngeal nerve-Styloglossus muscle along with IX nerve is related to the anteroinferior 1/3 of lateral wall of tonsil.

 

Option C: Internal carotid artery lies 2.5cm behind and lateral to tonsillar sinus.

 

Option D: Paratonsillar vein lies in the loose areolar tissue along the lateral aspect of the tonsil. The facial artery, its ascending palatine branch and its tonsillar branches, ascending pharyngeal artery also form its lateral relations for palatine tonsil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During a tonsillectomy, which is the surgical removal of the palatine tonsils, the external carotid artery is not typically affected.
  • The palatine tonsils are located in the tonsillar fossa between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches.
