  • While there are several structures in close proximity to the tonsils that could potentially be affected during surgery, such as the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), the tonsillar branches of the facial artery, and the lingual artery, the external carotid artery itself is located more deeply and laterally relative to the tonsil and is not directly involved in a standard tonsillectomy procedure. Therefore, it is generally not at risk during this surgery.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 153

choices.text: Optic Nerve and Floor of Orbit
Optic Nerve and Internal Carotid Artery
Optic Nerve and Nasolacrimal Duct
Orbital Floor and Nasolacrimal Duct

questions.text: Onodi and Haller Cells of Ethmoidal Labyrinth is seen in relation to following respectively:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic Nerve and Floor of Orbit

 

Option A:

 

  • Onodi cells and Haller cells are anatomical variations related to the ethmoidal air cells, which are part of the paranasal sinus system.

 

 

 

  • Sphenoethmoidal cells or onodi cells are related to optic nerve canal and internal carotid artery.
  • Haller cells related to orbital floor and Agger nasi cells related to lacrimal duct.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While Onodi cells are indeed related to the optic nerve due to their posterior and lateral extension towards the sphenoid sinus, they are not typically associated with the internal carotid artery. The internal carotid artery may be related to other sphenoid sinus structures but not specifically to Onodi cells.

 

Option C: Onodi cells are related to the optic nerve, but there is no direct association between Onodi cells and the nasolacrimal duct. The nasolacrimal duct primarily drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity and is located more anteriorly, not typically in close relation to the ethmoid air cells.

 

Option D: While Haller cells are associated with the floor of the orbit, they do not have a direct relationship with the nasolacrimal duct. Haller cells can impinge on the orbit's floor but are not specifically related to the nasolacrimal duct's anatomy or function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Onodi cells, also known as sphenoethmoidal cells, are air cells that extend posteriorly and laterally to the sphenoid sinus and can be closely associated with the optic nerve.

 

 

  • Due to their proximity, an infection or surgical intervention involving Onodi cells poses a risk to the optic nerve.
  • Haller cells are ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit (infraorbital ethmoid cells), potentially affecting the maxillary sinus' drainage and the health of the orbital contents.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 221

choices.text: Tensor Veli Palatini

questions.text: Muscle of the Soft Palate that Dilates the Auditory Tube:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tensor Veli Palatine

 

Option A:

 

  • Tensor veli palatini takes origin from lateral and fibrous lamina of auditory tubae, said to dilate the auditory tube and hence it is also called dilator tubae.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The Levator veli palatini muscle elevates the soft palate to close off the nasopharynx during swallowing and speech, preventing food from entering the nasal cavity. Although it plays a crucial role in the function of the soft palate, it does not directly dilate the auditory tube.

 

Option C: The palatopharyngeus muscle is involved in narrowing the pharyngeal cavity, lowering the soft palate, and helping in the elevation of the larynx and pharynx during swallowing. It does not have a direct role in the dilation of the auditory tube.

 

Option D: The musculus uvulae is a small muscle that makes up the bulk of the uvula and helps in elevating the uvula. By shortening and elevating the uvula, it plays a role in the function of the soft palate but does not contribute to the dilation of the auditory tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tensor Veli Palatini:

 

  • The tensor veli palatini muscle originates from the sphenoid bone and the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube.
  • It inserts into the palatine aponeurosis.
  • The primary function of the tensor veli palatini is to tense the soft palate and open the auditory tube during swallowing and yawning.
  • This action equalizes the pressure between the middle ear and the nasopharynx, which is crucial for proper hearing function.
  • The muscle is innervated by a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3), which is part of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 133

questions.text: Nasolacrimal Duct opens into:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Meatus

 

Option C:

 

The opening of nasolacrimal duct into inferior meatus is guarded by valve of hasner.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior meatus receives the posterior ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option B: Middle meatus receives-maxillary sinus, frontal sinus, anterior and middle ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option D: Sphenoidal sinus opens into sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasolacrimal duct drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.
  • It opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity, which is located beneath the inferior nasal concha (or turbinate).
  • This opening allows the tears that have been collected in the lacrimal sac to flow into the nasal cavity, where they can be reabsorbed or expelled.


Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 218

choices.text: The Piriform Fossa is situated on the Lateral wall of Laryngopharynx
The Piriform Fossa is traversed by recurrent Laryngeal Nerve
Laryngopharynx is supported behind by the bodies of C4 to C6 Vertebra
Piriform Fossa is separated from the Epiglottic Vallecula by the lateral Glosso Epiglottic fold

questions.text: A 75-year-old man celebrated his birthday with his family in a cruise. While he was eating his dinner he suddenly choked on a piece of mutton. He gasped that he had a bone stuck in his throat. Assuming that the bone was stuck in the piriform fossa, the following statements are correct except which?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The piriform fossa is traversed by recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The piriform fossa is traversed by internal laryngeal nerve which innervates the mucus membrane of pyriform fossa as well as mucosa of the larynx above the level of vocal folds.


 

 

  • Superior laryngeal vessels and internal laryngeal nerve pierce thyrohyoid membrane and traverse outside the mucus lining of the pyriform fossa from lateral to medial wall

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The piriform fossae are recesses located on either side of the laryngeal opening on the lateral walls of the laryngopharynx. They are common sites for foreign bodies to become lodged.

 

Option C. The laryngopharynx, which includes the region of the piriform fossa, extends from the level of the hyoid bone (C3) to the esophagus at the level of C6 vertebra.

 

Option D. The piriform fossa is separated from the vallecula, which is a space at the base of the tongue between the folds of mucous membrane passing from the tongue to the epiglottis (glossoepiglottic fold).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not traverse the piriform fossa. Instead, it runs in the tracheoesophageal groove and then ascends to the larynx behind the thyroid lobe, close to the laryngopharynx but not through the piriform fossa.

Boundaries

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No577
